content: The "Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act" establishes a Commission with specific duties, powers, and personnel matters. It includes provisions for a final report, Congressional hearings, authorization of appropriations, and termination of the Commission. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission to address rising medical malpractice premiums by proposing a comprehensive strategy. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President, representing various interests such as physicians, insurers, lawyers, and consumer protection. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President, representing various interests. Members include Senators, House Representatives, and individuals recommended by Senate and House leaders. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President, representing various interests. Presidential appointments are limited to one individual who is not part of the Executive Branch. Other appointments must have expertise in specific fields and not be officers or employees of the United States. Efforts are made to ensure diversity among Commission members. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President, representing various interests. Members appointed should represent a broad cross-section of regional and political perspectives in the United States and provide fresh insights into analyzing the medical malpractice insurance crisis. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President, representing various interests. Members appointed should represent a broad cross-section of regional and political perspectives in the United States. The Commission must hold its first meeting promptly, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for voting. Each member is entitled to one vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will investigate the relationship between malpractice insurance premiums, jury awards, healthcare accessibility, and physician retention. Recommendations will be based on statistical trends and testimony to address the medical malpractice liability insurance crisis. The Commission will also examine the nature of the medical malpractice insurance market and its similarities to other insurance lines, as well as the impact of the McCarran-Ferguson Act. The Commission will investigate the impact of the McCarran-Ferguson Act on the medical malpractice insurance market, federal role and recommendations for medical malpractice, efficacy of State-level legislation in insurance, insurer's investments and premium rate setting, role of jury awards in premium rates, and the relationship between premium rates and medical practice costs. SEC. 4. FINAL REPORT; CONGRESSIONAL HEARINGS. The Commission must submit a final report to the President and Congress within 16 months of the Act's enactment. The report should include findings, a strategy to address rising medical malpractice insurance rates, and recommendations for necessary actions. Members can also submit additional views. Congressional hearings by the Committee should follow within 6 months of the final report. Upon submission of the final report, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions will conduct hearings on the report. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. They must conduct at least 7 public hearings in various locations. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal government officers or employees. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided at authorized rates for agency employees. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can also procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission to implement the Act. The Comptroller General will audit the Commission's finances within 6 months of its termination. The Commission will dissolve 30 days after submitting its final report.
